msItem.incipit: Temporibus Etheldredi Regis sanctus Edmundus martirizatus fuit Cui successit alfredus siue aluredus
msItem.explicit: ab aldredo Eborac’ Archiepiscopo apud Westm’ solempniter est coronatus
msItem.note: Becomes a series of annals through 1142; on the MS generally, see Antonia Gransden, Historical Writing in England 2: c.1307 to the Early Sixteenth Century (London, 1982), 412–3 n. 156. A note added above the top line, ‘Ethelred Rex cepit regnare Anno domini DCCClj .’.

msItem.incipit:
Cronica de Rege Ethelredo Rege Angliecuius tem
[fol. 6] pore tota Anglia quod nota per Regem
msItem.explicit: ex Emma normannica genuit postmodum Alfredum et Edwardum
msItem.note: Includes (fol. 8rv) a note on the election of abbot Sampson of Bury in 1132.

msItem.rubric: De morte Edmundi Regis patre Regis Edgari qui dedit Sancto Edmundo villam de Beotricesworth Anno domini DCCCCxlo
msItem.incipit: Rex pijssimus anglorum Edmundus dum in festo Sancti Augustini
msItem.explicit: vt patet in Cronitis Cestrie Marcani et Hincden et Nobwic'

msItem.rubric: Carta sancti Edwardi Regis et confessoris |
msItem.incipit: [fol. 25v] Ego Edwardus Rex anglorum notifico in hijs litteris omnibus dei Fidelibus quod consiliatus sum
msItem.explicit: [fol. 35] solempniter est receptus hec Gilda in | suis Cronicis de Abbate Ancelmo

msItem.incipit: Willielmus dux Normandie primus Rex a conquestu qui apud london’ in die natalis
msItem.explicit: Rex illustrissimus qui regnauit Super Angliam 23. annos [later] Sepultusque est apud Wynesore [later] ’.
msItem.note: The blanks in the text filled and other material added, in a hand of s. xvi, extending the chronicle through Henry VII.

msItem.rubric: Tabula cronicarum Regum Anglie facta et compilata videlicet a primo Anno Willielmi Conquestoris usque ad annum xm. Regis henrici sexti
msItem.incipit: In primis dictus Willielmus erat electus in Regem Anglie in die natalis domini
msItem.explicit: [fol. 59v] et superest Edwardus quartus dei gracia Rex anglie et Francie Rex | illustrissimus
msItem.note: Most of these annals (along with the lists from fols. 103v–6 and 132v–3v) ed. Thomas Arnold, Memorials of St Edmund’s Abbey, RS 96/3 (1896), 291–300. On fol. 57, the English distich: ‘The ax was sharpe the stokke was harde in the xiiij. yere of kyng Richarde’ (IMEV 3306).

msItem.rubric: De translacione Episcopatus a Thetfordia vsque Norwicum Anno domini MoxCiiijo.vo. idus aprilis
msItem.incipit: Episcopatus de Thetfordia translatus est apud Norwicum ab herberto losenge tunc ibidem episcopo
msItem.explicit: et in Cenomannice Ecclesia Sancti Iuliani sepultus est Vt patet in dicta Cronica
msItem.note: Followed by annals of a generally ecclesiastical stripe, including records of land transactions involving Bury interests, up to the early thirteenth century; then the compiler navigates back into records of earlier kings.

msItem.incipit: Deus in Cuius manu corda sunt regum qui est humilium consolator et fidelium fortitudo et protector omnium
msItem.explicit: vt in caritate diuina firmati nullis temptacionibus a te separentur

msItem.incipit: Nota pro abbate Roberto Ixworth decretorum doctore qui multum pro preseruacione sue religionis et sue ecclesie
msItem.explicit: Annus A parliamento apud buryam sancti Edmundi xxxvj.
msItem.note: Ending with a list of abbots of Bury through the time of Edward II (fols. 103–4), with further entries on fourteenth-century Bury affairs, a table of dates of construction of various abbeys (fols. 107–8), eventually becoming further notes on Bury history.

msItem.rubric: Oraciones valde deuote dicente sunt pro pestilencia et morbo epidimie
msItem.incipit: O martir sebastiane magna est fides tua intercede pro nobis ad dominum nostrum
msItem.explicit: Wil Iohan Robertus Ixworth Hynghamque Ricardus 2’. Ratlisden Et sequitur Thomas cristo viuat Pius abbas
msItem.note: Includes (fol. 118rv) a hymn: ‘Aue gemma curatorum | O Iohannes flos doctorum | Rector de merstonia ’ and very quickly becomes a variety of notes on St Edmund, his translations, etc., ending with another list of abbots of Bury. The text on fol. 133rv is probably in a different hand (writing after 1479, when Thomas Rattlesden became abbot) and added to fill out the fragmentary list of abbots, with notes on holders of the dependant parishes Totyngham and Drayton, Barnham, and Ratlisden. Hyngham, entered under Barnham, is then probably not the mid-fifteenth-century Bury abbot of the name, but a known Bury monk, reader of English, and scribe; see Richard Beadle, ‘Monk Thomas Hyngham’s Hand in the Macro Manuscript’, in Beadle and A.J. Piper (eds.), New Science out of Old Books: Studies in Manuscripts and Early Printed Books in Honour of A. I. Doyle (Aldershot, 1995), 315–41 at 316–17.

collation.formula: 16 2–48 56 6–108 ,116 [fol. 92, a booklet boundary] 12–168 172 (fols. 133 + iv, an added bifolium, probably later; the second blank, now pasted to paper, and a former pastedown).
collation.signatures: All leaves in the first half of each quire after the first signed with a letter and an arabic numeral; in this system, quires 2–16 = c–M, A–E.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 16 lines to the page. Prickings; bounded and ruled in black ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in mixed anglicana/secretary (anglicana a, secretary w and g). Punctuation by point and derivative of punctus versus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Item 1 has red paraphs for separate textual sections and underlining of important sections in text ink.
The ‘Orationes ualde deuote’ at the head of item 10 include headings and paraphs in red, and some 1-line red lombards.

binding.p: A modern replacement. Sewn on three thongs. At the front, a marbled paper leaf and two paper flyleaves; at the rear, a paper flyleaf and another marbled leaf (v–vi).

history.provenance: ‘Anno domini MoCCCClviijo. In Festo apostolorum Philippi et Iacobi Thomas Croftis habitum recepit cum alijs tribus’ (fol. 35v, in the blank following the explicit of item 4, boxed in red) (assigned to Bury on the basis of contents, Ker, MLGB 22). A Thomas Crofts kt. of Drosthale who d. 1442/3, perhaps kin of this Thomas, gave books to two Suffolk houses, Flixton (OSA nuns) and Sibton (OCist); see Ker, MLGB 263, 306.
‘Epitome chronicarum cenobij de Bury’ (fol. 1, vertically in the gutter, s. xvii).
